comments:
I've just attempted to do a debug with 3.0 (just downloaded after
returning from JavaOne) and I am getting this error:

FATAL ERROR in native method: No transports initialized
Transport dt_socket failed to initialize, rc = 509. 

I am using Windows XP SP1.  I have been using Eclipse since 1.0 and have  never
had a problem until I installed 3.0.

I just tested with 2.1.3 and the debugging works just file there.  

I have deleted all my external plugins, the configurations subdirectory under
Eclipse and created a new workspace.  I created a brand new project, with a new
class (HelloWorld) and it does exactly the same thing and I get the exact same
error.

I am not running any local FireWall and there is this entry in the log:

!MESSAGE Cannot connect to VM

I am running under JDK 1.5 beta 2 and use the following startup command:

C:\apps\eclipse3x\eclipse.exe -data C:\apps\workspace30 -vm
c:\apps\jdk14\jre\bin\javaw   -vmargs -Xmx512m

Additionally, this is the stack trace found in the log:

java.net.SocketException: socket closed
	at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.socketAccept(Native Method)
	at java.net.PlainSocketImpl.accept(PlainSocketImpl.java:353)
	at java.net.ServerSocket.implAccept(ServerSocket.java:448)
	at java.net.ServerSocket.accept(ServerSocket.java:419)
	at
org.eclipse.jdi.internal.connect.SocketTransportImpl.accept(SocketTransportImpl.java:87)
	at
org.eclipse.jdi.internal.connect.SocketListeningConnectorImpl.accept(SocketListeningConnectorImpl.java:124)
	at
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.launching.StandardVMDebugger$ConnectRunnable.run(StandardVMDebugger.java:78)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:534)

JDK 1.5 is not yet supported by Eclipse. Do you have the same problem running 
1.4.2?

Cannot reproduce. I can launch Eclipse 3.0 on JDK 1.4.2 and debug on JDK 1.5
beta 2 no problem. Are you getting this problem consistently? If so, have you
tried starting over from scratch with a new Eclipse 3.0 install (as opposed to
installing and then deleting plugins)? It shouldn't make any difference, but it
would be good to try.

From bug 44270 comment 11 and 12, it looks like your VM installation is messed
up such that the debug libraries aren't present. Did you install a JRE instead
of a JDK? If not, you might have got a bad download or something. I'd try
grabbing the JDK again and re-installing.

I uninstalled 1.5 and used the 1.4 install and debugging does again work.   I
thought the use of the -vm should force Eclipse to startup the specified JVM,
with was 1.4.2_04.  Does that not work?
